text: since the age of the dinosaurs sea
turtles have inhabited the world's
oceans but in recent years commercial
fishing poaching and warmer seas have
placed them on the brink of extinction
leatherbacks
plummeted over the last 20 years from
say 90,000 breeding females to only
2,000 in the eastern Pacific
so when populations are reduced so
dramatically they are extremely
vulnerable more than ever the survival
of baby turtles is critical but when
females emerge from the ocean to nest on
beaches like this one at Playa han kyul
in Costa Rica their centuries-old
breeding rituals fail in a quickly
changing world besides a curious dog or
hungry poacher turtle nests are
extremely vulnerable to the effects of
global warming rising sea levels have
eaten away at nesting beaches and turtle
eggs are sensitive to minut changes in
sand temperature really global warming
can have an amazing impact on this
animal as reptiles they fully depend on
the Sun for the incubation of the eggs
in the sand and moreover the sex of
these animals is determined by the
temperature of incubation if the
temperature in the incubation chamber
goes above 29 degrees you get overall
more females than males but if the
temperature rises above 34 all the eggs
boil essentially and the embryos die 34
degrees Celsius roughly 93 degrees
Fahrenheit is a common sand temperature
here but in kiyul a makeshift
solution may be giving these slow to
adapt creatures a last chance at
survival one night under the cover of
darkness this endangered Olive Ridley
turtle lays 100 eggs in the sand she
buries them and leaves the eggs to hatch
on their own
soon after the turtle leaves a local
youth in Hongqiao digs up the eggs
turtle eggs were once a popular delicacy
in this small coastal town but this boy
is no poacher at least not anymore he is
a paid employee of a group of young
conservationists called the Bala Boys
Bala is the Spanish word for leatherback
turtle the problem we had with the local
community was that they were poaching
the eggs at night it's safe to say that
a majority of the boys were poachers I
think now the boys are very professional
and they know a lot about turtles
Gabrielle Francia a marine biologist
started this innovative program in 2005
his goal is to save the turtles from
extinction one nest at a time every
night the BAU the boys patrol the
beaches to make sure that poachers don't
illegally steal eggs and when they do
find a turtle nest they move the eggs to
a hatchery the fenced in and shaded
hatchery will protect them during the
vulnerable incubation period and
hopefully balance the sexes we try to
keep the temperature under eighty nine
point six degrees we know that at 85
degrees 50 percent males and 50% females
will hatch in effect the balla boys act
as adoptive father's to the parentless
turtle eggs but they don't always find
every nest recently they discovered a
batch of eggs that had overheated under
the black sand this actually looks like
it burned inside the shell the yolk
looks like it was cooked because of the
high temperature but cooler sand alone
will not save the turtles further up the
Pacific coast in Playa Grande
environmentalists say development puts
the turtles at risk legions of Turtles
used to nest at Playa Grande in fact the
bustling surf town built its tourism
industry around the turtle population
and established a national park to
protect leatherback turtles tourists
still flock to the beaches to see the
animals I'm from Sweden
like no turtles except the ones in an
aquarium small ones and of course one
day we hope to be here on the beach and
see one of those great rat holes
but a ranger at the national parks as
the turtle population has dwindled
because of over development ten years
ago there are 400 nesting Turtles last
year there were only 32 humans are
invading their nesting grounds large
properties sit on the edge of the beach
and trees have been cut down for
unobstructed ocean views if FBI belong
in the natural barrier that the turtles
need to lay eggs is gone because of the
construction we have to do our part and
let people know what's happening to the
turtles through their small efforts
Gabrielle Francia and his bowel a boys
are doing their part to help the sea
turtles while the Sun sets they make
their way down to the beach to release
the baby turtles they have nurtured
against all the odds the turtles make
their way into the city
